utterance.content: Barely above normal.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: My leg gave us ‘till 11:15. I’ll talk to Wilson about lymphoma, ANA for lupus, radioimmunoassay for drugs, and you… you test for whatever you thought it was. I’ve got a date with a pharmacist.

utterance.speaker: House

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, I guess we’ll never know.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No way! I love the clinic.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You love the pills. Two weeks.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Pills don’t make me high. They make me neutral.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: A month.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re on, mister.

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: Drugs could cause this?

utterance.content: Cocaine and meth are very hard on the blood system. Has he had any erratic behavior?

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: No, but… She was in rehab in the 9th grade. She’s supposedly clean now, but –

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: She obviously cares for him.

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: Yeah, what she cared about was the car. Anniversary present from my wife. We drove it up north to watch the leaves change. She was dead a year later. Cancer.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I’m sorry. Mr. Foster, we’re going to test Keith for drugs.

utterance.speaker: Keith
utterance.content: I don’t do drugs.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It’s not that we don’t trust you, but…

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: His hair will tell us any drugs he’s taken in the past sixty days. It’s kind of like rings on a tree.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Negative.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Have you been sick?

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: No, nothing.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Have you been out of the country?

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: We went to China, but we got all of our shots before we left.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It could be an infection. We’re going to give him a gallium scan just to be safe. We inject a radioactive isotope into his bloodstream, and we check to see if there’s inflammation anywhere in the body.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Has he ever complained of any joint pain? Sensitivity to light, rashes…

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: No, no, nothing.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Any relatives ever been diagnosed with lupus?

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: I don’t even know that that is.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: In simple terms, the body becomes allergic to itself. The immune system attacks healthy cells in the circulatory system and destroys them.

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: Would it be treatable?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It can be manageable.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We can test for the antibodies. 95% of patients with lupus test positive for ANA.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Not cloudy. Negative.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: What about bruising? He ever complain about tenderness under his arms or his groin?

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: I’m not sure he’d tell me if he did. I guess I really don’t know what’s going on in his life.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He’s a teenager. What type of cancer did your wife have?

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: Pancreatic.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It’s his lymph nodes we’re concerned about. We’re going to do a biopsy to check for lymphoma.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Okay, you feel this?

utterance.speaker: Keith
utterance.content: No.

utterance.content: Good.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Nothing.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Negative for drugs. ANA was negative, gallium scan was clear…

utterance.speaker: House

utterance.speaker: Foreman

utterance.content: You okay?

utterance.speaker: Keith
utterance.content: Excuse me, someone? Help, please?

utterance.speaker: House

utterance.speaker: Keith

utterance.speaker: Keith

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Coumadin would dissolve the clot, fix his eyesight.

utterance.content: Surgery’s out for the same reason.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We have two hours to figure this out. Either we restore the blood flow or he loses the eye.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Forget the eye. Tell him to use the other one to look on the bright side. The clot tells us something. It could help us figure out what he has, which could mean he gets to live. Differential diagnosis, people. How does internal bleeding suddenly start clotting?

utterance.content: It makes no sense, they’re opposing processes.

utterance.content: I was lonely.

utterance.content: Well, go see Cuddy. She needs a friend.

utterance.content: That’s why you’re here? She wants you to keep an eye on me, make sure I don’t cheat.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m fine.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: What’s going on?

utterance.content: Withdrawal symptoms. Not applicable. The only side-effects I’m going to have are some pain and thirty days of freedom. Am I the only one who’s concerned about a dying kid? If it’s not lupus, what else?

utterance.content: Right. Clot slips off, travels through the artery, and gets backed up in the eye.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m sorry, I wasn’t paying attention. What happened?

utterance.content: It’s an infection. In his heart?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Is it my birthday?

utterance.content: The envious, jealous, I’m-married-and-I-can’t-do-anything logic! Hello.

utterance.content: Not a fan of the stroganoff?

utterance.content: I’m not hungry.

utterance.content: The antibiotics can cause nausea.

utterance.content: The blood clot isn’t life-threatening. We’re focusing on figuring out the cause of your problems.

utterance.content: So the blindness will be permanent, won’t it?

utterance.speaker: House

utterance.speaker: Woman

utterance.content: Looks like you had a masseuse. Help the pain?

utterance.content: I know. Kid’s echo was normal, no sign of any vegetations on heart valves.

utterance.content: So, double the dosage. 70mg.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: He’s got a clot in his retinal –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Read the memo.

utterance.content: If we remove some of the liquid from the eye itself, the Vitreous humor, it might make some extra room around the retinal artery.

utterance.content: I can see you.

utterance.speaker: Pam

utterance.speaker: Keith

utterance.speaker: Pam

utterance.content: ALT and GDT were in the tank. Our antibiotics –

utterance.content: Would not have caused this.

utterance.content: She must have given him drugs.

utterance.content: I wouldn’t do that!

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: What is your problem?

utterance.content: His son’s dying and you’re mocking him?

utterance.content: It was a dumb question.

utterance.speaker: Cameron

utterance.content: Hemolytic anemia doesn’t cause liver damage. Add the fact he’s coughing blood, you’ve got three of the indicators of organ-threatening lupus.

utterance.speaker: House

utterance.speaker: House

utterance.content: But there isn’t a treatment for hepatitis-E. Either he’ll get better on his own or he’ll continue to deteriorate.

utterance.content: If he’s got hep-E that’s only going to make him worse!

utterance.content: Not as much. Goldilocks, people. It won’t hurt him so much that it’ll kill him, and it won’t hurt him so little that we can’t tell. It’ll hurt him just right. And if it does nothing…

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We’ll know it’s not hep-E and start treating him for lupus.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Now watch me do it while drinking a glass of water.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What do we tell the dad? “We think your kid has lupus, so we’re gonna treat him for hepatitis-E? And oh yeah, if it really is hep-E, we’re not actually giving him hep-E medication, so it’s gonna make him worse, not better?”

utterance.content: You think he’ll go for that?

utterance.content: So you want us to lie?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No. I want you to lie.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Why me?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Because he trusts you.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: This is a mistake.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: This is a lawsuit.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Hep-E is possible. House always pulls these stunts and he’s right more often –

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He’s delaying treatment because of a one-in-a-million chance that even he doesn’t think is the problem.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I don’t want to lie to him.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Then don’t.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: And get fired?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Like he’s going to fire you, he loves you.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I’ve got to do something, the kid needs treatment.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Treat him for lupus.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: That will get you fired.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You really think House is losing it?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: He’s fine. He knows what he’s doing.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We’re recommending a drug called solumedrol.

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: For hepatitis? Did that show up on his blood tests?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: The tests are never 100% accurate.

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: Well, then all the other tests could be wrong, too. This could still be an infection or cancer.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Um, they don’t fit any of the most recent symptoms.

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: Well, what, just hepatitis does? I know, I know, I know, you can never be sure. When Linda was in the hospital, the doctor told us there was this aggressive experimental treatment which might extend her life by two or three years. We figured if there was any hope at all that we could have her with us a little while longer, it would be worth it. 3 weeks later, she was gone.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I don’t think it’s hepatitis. I think your son has lupus.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I think it’s broken. What did you do?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Accidentally closed the car door on it.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No. Door would have broken the skin. This looks like something hard and smooth smashed it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I want my lawyer.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: The brain has a gating mechanism for pain. Registers the most severe injury and blocks out the others. Did it work?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, my hand hurts like hell. Yeah, I feel much better.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Huh.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Don’t splint it. I want to be able to bang it against the wall if I need to administer another dose. Just… tape it up.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Why did you tell Cameron to lie to Mr. Foster?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Make it tight will ya.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Answer me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nothing I could say is going to change how you feel, and nothing could come out of your reaction that is going to change what I plan to do, so I prefer to say nothing.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: So, that was you just saying nothing.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Uh-huh.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: The guy is furious.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And scared.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: So, what are you going to do? The father’s insisting on the lupus treatment.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, Cameron told me and I told her to tell him no.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Well, you can’t just sit back and let the kid die.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Neither can the father.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: So that’s your plan? You’re gonna play chicken with the kid’s life?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, he’s the dad. I should win easily.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Take the week off.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What, ‘cause I lied to a patient? I take risks, sometimes patients die. But not taking risks causes more patients to die, so I guess my biggest problem is I’ve been cursed with the ability to do the math.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I told him that you wouldn’t treat him for the lupus until –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What did he say?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He said he wanted to transfer Keith to another hospital.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: He’s not stable enough, he’d never make it through the door!

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: That’s what I told him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And that’s when he caved.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Yeah. He agreed to do it your way.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Two plus two equals four.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: If it is hepatitis-E we should begin to see a marked decline in liver function tests within the hour.

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: Why bother explaining it to me? It’s not like I have any choice in the matter.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: If there’s no hep-E we’ll start treatment for lupus immediately.

utterance.speaker: Keith
utterance.content: Ouch!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Keith? What’s wrong?

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: What’s happening?

utterance.speaker: Keith
utterance.content: Get off!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Keith? It’s Dr. Chase, where does it hurt?

utterance.speaker: Keith
utterance.content: Jules, no!

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He’s hallucinating.

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: Is this from the medicine?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We haven’t started the medicine.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Keith, we’re in the hospital. Keith, there’s nothing on you.

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: Keith, Keith, Keith! You okay, buddy?

utterance.speaker: Keith
utterance.content: I think I wet the bed.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Don’t worry about it, it’s fine. Let’s get you up.

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: Oh, God!

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He’s had a major bleed. Bright red blood per rectum.

utterance.speaker: Keith
utterance.content: I didn’t mean to, I’m sorry.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: He’s going into hypervolemic shock. Pressure’s 60, heart rate’s 140.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We need an angiography, stat!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Angiography revealed major upper and lower GI bleeding, severe hemodynamic compromise, and liver failure.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: He’s also hallucinating. Thinks he’s being talked to by someone named “Jules”.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Hallucinations are a symptom of psychosis, which is the fourth diagnostic criterion. It’s official. This is lupus.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Who’s Jules? Any mention of her in the medical history?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It doesn’t matter what he’s hallucinating about, it matters why! It’s lupus!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: There’s no need to get snippy. This kind of lupus takes years to get to this point, it’s been a week.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Yeah, and a 16-year-old kid shouldn’t have hemolytic anemia, or be bleeding out of every orifice, but he is. We had an opportunity to treat this, instead we diddled around with hepatitis-E and now it’s too late. He needs a new liver. We screwed up.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re saying I screwed up.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Then why didn’t you just say that?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You gonna just blame this on her?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Did you agree with my recommendation to treat for hep-E?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: No, I didn’t.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: And she made herself quite clear.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And then she went and lied to the father. That’s why you’re angry.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Yeah, I trusted you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You always trust me. Big mistake. Lupus is a bad diagnosis.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It’s the best diagnosis we’ve got.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That doesn’t make it good.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No, it just makes it this kid’s only chance to live.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Put him on the transplant list. And make sure Cuddy knows, see if she can do anything to get him close to the top. Cafeteria. Stay away from the sushi.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: And what happened to your hand?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Got stuck in a drawer.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Yeah, right. You’re going through withdrawal.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, I am going through pain. Pain causes nausea.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I took this job to work with you, not cover your ass. Your Vicodin.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And your solution is to give me drugs. It’s interesting.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No. Now I’m covering my ass. Take your pills before you kill this kid.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Lupus is normally treated with medication, but in Keith’s case the disease is too advanced.

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: Because you lied. Because House wanted to play games with my son’s life.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: There’s no way to really tell what progression the disease may take –

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You’re right, and I’m sorry.

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: So what do we do?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He needs a new liver.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: There are over 15,000 patients on the transplant list.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: But how many are about to bleed to death unless they get a new liver?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: In Jersey? I’d say, uh, twenty. 2000 patients die each year because a donor liver can’t be found, that’s almost five a day.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So he’s screwed.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I’ll see what I can do.

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: Could I donate part of my liver?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Sorry, you’re a different blood type.

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: So we just wait?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I’m afraid so.

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: And hope for someone to die.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Who’s Jules?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Dr. House, you should get back to your office –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Jules. There’s no Jules in the history.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It was a hallucination.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Of what?

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: Our cat. Does this matter?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No, I’m sorry. We’ll continue the transfusions and the treatment for the anemia and liver failure while we’re waiting for a donor.

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: How long can he wait?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Not long.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don’t think this is lupus.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I don’t think this is lupus. Come on, let’s just go –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Your fourth diagnostic criterion of lupus is psychosis; this is just a kid missing his cat.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: He was being attacked by an animal that wasn’t in the room. That’s psychosis.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: There’s a difference between psychosis and hallucination.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So, if he was imagining a fake cat it’d be lupus, but since it was a real cat it’s not? Take your damn pills.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Psychosis requires –

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: There’s no cat! Jules is dead.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You have a dead family pet, and you never mentioned it? Nice family history.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Family history is asking about family members, meaning people related to the patient. Let’s go.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How did the cat die?

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: Can you get him out of here?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Dr. House, come on, let’s go –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What happened to the cat?

utterance.speaker: Pam
utterance.content: Old age. She was fifteen years old.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: When?

utterance.speaker: Pam
utterance.content: About a month ago?

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: Does this have anything to do with –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Where’d she sleep?

utterance.speaker: Pam
utterance.content: With Keith.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: This is not a cat allergy.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s not lupus. Where is Jules?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Four years of college, four at med school, two years of residency, another four of sub-specialty training, and where do I end up?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Talking instead of digging. Come on, the ground’s frozen solid.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What’s that?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Out of the way! We have the liver. Prep OR 4.

utterance.speaker: Anesthesiologist
utterance.content: All right, Keith. Start counting backward from ten.

utterance.speaker: Keith
utterance.content: Ten… nine… eight…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Stop the gases.

utterance.speaker: Hourani
utterance.content: What the hell are you doing, House?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Saving a sixteen-year-old kid from a lifetime of immunosuppressant drugs and a very nasty scar. This kid doesn’t have lupoid hepatitis. He has acute naphthalene toxicity.

utterance.speaker: Hourani
utterance.content: Naphthalene. You’re talking about mothballs.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nope. Termites. They create naphthalene to protect their nests, which I’m assuming is rather large and is inside all four walls of his bedroom at home.

utterance.speaker: Hourani
utterance.content: And your assumption is based on what?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The autopsy I just conducted on his pet cat.

utterance.speaker: Hourani
utterance.content: Call Cuddy. And security.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You are not removing that kid’s liver.

utterance.speaker: Hourani
utterance.content: NOW! Have you completely lost your mind?!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, but I have been feeling a little sick lately. Achoo!

utterance.speaker: Anesthesiologist
utterance.content: There’s no way we can do this surgery now.

utterance.speaker: Hourani
utterance.content: You think?!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You’ve already cost him his liver, don’t kill him too!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why are you so eager to cut into a healthy kid?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Healthy? He’s in the toilet!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He just needs some chicken soup.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I’m telling Hourani to re-scrub. We’re doing this transplant.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, you’re not.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You said it! If Keith’s symptoms had an environmental cause, they would have disappeared as soon as he got here.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: They’ve only gotten worse.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If the food here wasn’t one step below Riker’s Island he would’ve gotten better. He’s lost fourteen pounds.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Yeah, sure. This is nothing but a dietary thing.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Naphthalene is a gas, a fat soluble gas. The kid breathes it in, it gets stored in his fat cells. Outside the hospital his body burned protein and carbs for energy, and the naphthalene stayed in fat. But once the car accident put him in the hospital, and he started losing weight , his body had to get its energy somewhere else. It started to burn fat. The floodgates opened, the poison poured into his system.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So, getting away from the poison is what poisoned him?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Getting him away from his dad’s meatloaf is what’s killing him.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You wanna explain to me why you stopped the surgery? N – Oh, my God! My God.

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: I want him locked up!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Hey! Take it easy.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Your cat did not die of old age. He died of massive internal bleeding and acute liver failure caused by naphthalene poisoning, the exact same thing your son has.

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: You lie to me, you mess up my son’s surgery, and now you expect me to trust you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Give me twenty-four hours, we’ll pump your son full of calories –

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: That liver is going to somebody right now.

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: We’re doing that surgery.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If you do the surgery, you’ll be killing a mother of four.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Father of three.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I was guessing.

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: Like you are now?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Naphthalene poisoning is the best explanation we have for what’s wrong with your son. It explains the internal bleeding, the hemolytic anemia, the liver failure… it also predicts what’ll happen next. If you do the surgery he’s gonna lay on that table for fourteen hours while his body continues to burn fat and release poison into his system. Either way, I did you a favor. He’s awake now, you’ve got a chance to say goodbye.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I think you should trust Dr. House.

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: Give the liver to the other guy.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: INR is down, and his blood count is climbing. It means you made the right call. His liver is healing. He’s gonna be just fine. [Dad hugs his son, and Pam grabs Keith’s hand. The dad grabs Pam’s arm, too, and everyone is happy.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You made it a week.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And won my prize.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Congratulations.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Cuddy’s a sucker. I would have done it for two weeks off.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah, it was a piece of cake. You learn anything?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, I’m an addict.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Uh, okay.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m not stopping.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: There are programs. Cuddy would give you the time. You could get on a different pain management regimen –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don’t need to stop.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You just said…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I said I was an addict. I didn’t say I had a problem. I pay my bills, I make my meals. I function.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Is that all you want? You have no relationships.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don’t want any relationships.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You alienate people.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’ve been alienating people since I was three.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Oh, come on! Drop it! You don’t think you’ve changed in the last few years?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, of, of course I have. I’ve, I’ve gotten older. My hair’s gotten thinner. Sometimes I’m bored, sometimes I’m lonely, sometimes I wonder what it all means.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No, I was there! You are not just a regular guy who’s getting older, you’ve changed! You’re miserable, and you’re afraid to face yourself –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Of course I’ve changed!

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: And everything’s the leg? Nothing’s the pills? They haven’t done a thing to you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: They let me do my job, and they take away my pain.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: How’d it go?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: He admitted he’s addicted to the narcotics –

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Well, admitting you have a problem is the first –

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: -- and he says it’s not a problem. Maybe it’s not. What do I know?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: What are you going to do?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Nothing. I’ve done enough damage.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Better hope he never finds out that that was your idea.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: He’d never believe it.
